articles.headline: Commerzbank of Germany to Pay $1.5 Billion in U.S. Case
articles.snippet: Commerzbank, one of Germany’s largest lenders, was accused of sending tainted money through the American financial system.
articles.abstract: Commerzbank, one of Germany’s largest lenders, was accused of sending tainted money through the American financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pursuing a trail of illicit money from Geneva to Paris with stops in London, the United States authorities built a sweeping crackdown on some of Europe’s biggest banks.

articles.headline: Once Unique, LeapFrog Has Rivals in the Educational Toy Market
articles.snippet: LeapFrog, a dominant maker of educational toys and games, has watched its sales plummet because of cheaper alternatives.
articles.abstract: LeapFrog, a dominant maker of educational toys and games, has watched its sales plummet because of cheaper alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a weekday afternoon, Flora Bojadziev, a chef from Harlem, browsed through a Toys “R” Us in Manhattan.

articles.headline: From the Gates Foundation, Direct Investment, Not Just Grants
articles.snippet: The philanthropic giant is deploying funds and influence into for-profit companies with bright ideas, instead of focusing only on grants to nonprofits.
articles.abstract: The philanthropic giant is deploying funds and influence into for-profit companies with bright ideas, instead of focusing only on grants to nonprofits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Ebola crisis underscored a problem that vexes experts in global health: Vaccines are one of the most cost-effective ways to save lives, especially in developing countries, yet traditional vaccines can take years to develop.

articles.headline: Just as Ferguson Was Making Progress, Shooting Deals a Setback
articles.snippet: Just as Ferguson, Mo., seemed to be moving past the stunning abuses detailed by the Justice Department, four gunshots on Thursday threatened to rekindle tensions.
articles.abstract: Just as Ferguson, Mo., seemed to be moving past the stunning abuses detailed by the Justice Department, four gunshots on Thursday threatened to rekindle tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — In her three years as a city councilwoman, Kim Tihen has not been afraid to speak against the powers in her own city.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Eli Yokley

articles.headline: Battered but Unbowed, ISIS Is Still on Offensive
articles.snippet: In the seven months since allied warplanes in the American-led campaign began bombing select Islamic State targets, the Sunni militancy is holding its own.
articles.abstract: In the seven months since allied warplanes in the American-led campaign began bombing select Islamic State targets, the Sunni militancy is holding its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State is facing growing dissension among its rank-and-file fighters and struggling to govern towns and villages it has seized, but the militant Sunni group is still managing to launch attacks and expand its ideological reach outside of Iraq and Syria, senior American officials said.

articles.headline: Putin Has Vanished, but Rumors Are Popping Up Everywhere
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has not been seen in public since last week, and the rumor mill has gone into overdrive, churning out possible explanations from the simple to the salacious to the sinister.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has not been seen in public since last week, and the rumor mill has gone into overdrive, churning out possible explanations from the simple to the salacious to the sinister.

articles.headline: Defense in Marathon Bombing Has Echo of Clarence Darrow
articles.snippet: When Dzhokhar Tsarnaev’s lead lawyer admitted her client’s role in the Boston Marathon bombings, she was using a play from Clarence Darrow’s book.
articles.abstract: When Dzhokhar Tsarnaev’s lead lawyer admitted her client’s role in the Boston Marathon bombings, she was using a play from Clarence Darrow’s book.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Judy Clarke, the lead defense lawyer for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, announced at the outset of his trial last week that her client was responsible for the Boston Marathon bombings, she was following a strategy laid out by Clarence Darrow almost a century ago.

articles.headline: A Bespoke Perfume Doesn’t Come Cheap
articles.snippet: Getting your own signature scent can cost thousands of dollars, by one estimate $30,000 to $50,000. For some women, it’s worth it.
articles.abstract: Getting your own signature scent can cost thousands of dollars, by one estimate $30,000 to $50,000. For some women, it’s worth it.
articles.lead_paragraph: As part of a trip to France in 1984 to study floral painting, Dianne Bernhard spent time in Monet’s gardens at Giverny. It was there, among the flowers that inspired him, that she heard Cartier was creating a new perfume in Paris made with jasmine, roses and vanilla.
